displayed_text: Family Member: Never mind then. Doctor: Depending on the cryo if you decide to go with that and all of that and when Dr. C____ does it, then your next appointments will be changed Patient: Yep. Doctor: according to that. Okay? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Sound like a plan? Patient: Yeah it’s a plan. Patient: There he is. Doctor: Wow alright, thank you. I’ll be back. Hello. Patient: Hi. Doctor: Okay so any questions, any concerns? Patient: Uh I have to tell Dr. C____, but I’m gonna go for it.

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: -and for that immunotherapy six hundred thousand dollars. So Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: We’re trying not to let the insurance companies … for a different indication and insurance companies… Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: you have five FDA approved therapies. (xx) Patient: Okay. I wanna discuss with Dr. L___ who is my oncolgoist said I should really Doctor: I communicate with her, etcetera notes, translated to him real time so to speak. Patient: Okay. I understand that you’re Doctor: see in the notes Patient: Um I did a couple of months ago. Yeah because I did something PSA… Doctor: Okay. And did you plans in the future?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They will go and look at your insurance. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Figure out what X is going to cost. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: What’s the best pharmacy to get it from? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And, you know, is it a mail-order thing? And if it’s crazy, is there a different thing we can do? Uh, the other thing to say about Zytiga, is it’s going to be generic soon, but I’m not sure it, if we’re quite there yet. I’m not sure. I can find that out. But, uh, so if you tell me, geez, I really don’t want to take prednisone, then I would do the Xtandi. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Otherwise, I would do the Zytiga. Patient: Yeah. I don’t really want to take prednisone. I saw how it affected her. Doctor: Okay.

Healthcare Professional: The paper towel looks like. Doctor: You said it’s okay? Okay. How are you? Patient: Hum, all right, except my neck hurts where that rod is. Doctor: Okay. And, huh, so you scored your pain a six. Was that for that pain or to the abdomen? Patient: Oh, that’s when, huh, they gave me the needle. I told her. Doctor: Okay. Good. But six isn’t your neck or-? Patient: Huh, I would say, sometimes it’s a five on my neck, especially when I turn it. Doctor: Okay. And so- Patient: Before, it was turning to the left and it was turning to the right because I wanted to start driving. But now, when I turn it to the left it seems like right there you can feel the bone. Doctor: So you’ve not been able to drive yet because you can’t twist your neck enough? Patient: Right. Family Member: And on your (voice)

Patient: Okay. So (clears throat) Doctor: Uh usually they’ve told us a turn-around of one week after they get it Patient: Okay. Doctor: so I would say by a couple of weeks we should know. Patient: Alright. So are you needing more blood today or you already have enough blood? Yes. Yeah. Doctor: Now for this study you have to come back within ten days or so from today to get uh do the endo study stuff. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: So I was hoping at that point if we have some answers for you we can even get… Family Member: Mm, even get started. Doctor: … start anticipating and making some decisions about the other thing. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Patient: That’ll work. Doctor: So I was gonna say you should sign the pre-screening consent if that’s okay with you and send the blood test out.

Patient: Oh sure Doctor: But, if you don’t have any nausea, we have done everything that we needed to do and you feel great, you’ve got company to talk about – Hey, that wasn’t so bad. Family Member: Alright. Doctor: But, yeah, uh, you’ve gotta have a partner on those days. Patient: That’s fine. Just wanted to Doctor: There is no need to stay. She could leave for a couple of hours and come back. (chuckles) Family Member: Mmmmm. Doctor: Umm, but. Patient: How long then is, I know the infusion is like half an hour or something? Healthcare Professional: It’s an hour. Patient: It’s an hour. Okay. Then, how long before I get released? Doctor: Uh, the first time, they watch it for a half hour or so just to make sure you don’t have an allergic reaction.

Family Member: Fifth. Doctor: Fifth? We would need to, again, hold the drug. Because even at the lower dose of two-fifty, it’s still causing, you know, that significant anemia. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, I just want to get a sense from you whether you think you might, you know, want to stick with this for about two more months until the next set of scans? Whether you feel that you’ve had enough and you want to try something new? Or like where are you at with this? Patient: Well- Family Member: So, can I give you my perspective-? Doctor: Yeah. Please. Yes. Family Member: Of how I see it going? And then he can correct me if I’m wrong. But I feel like, um, D___ is in pain often, and, um, it’s, I would say the past two weeks, I would say like maybe last week, maybe a week and a half ago, he was in a lot of pain and very weak, from my perspective, what I am seeing. And, um, so often, and often would mean almost nightly, I am rubbing him with either Salonpas or Aspercreme or Bengay, one of the three, on his back, shoulders, legs, so that he can feel comfortable enough so he can lay down and rest. So, you know, that’s how I see it. I don’t know if he feels, if maybe I’m interpreting his pain to be more than it is, but when he asks me to rub, you know, rub something on his back, in my mind it’s pain. When I look at his face, I see that he’s in pain. So that’s what I see. And, you know, it might be that he’s like no, P___, it’s not that bad. On a scale of one to ten, it might be seven, but when I look at him, I’m seeing eight, nine. Doctor: We’ve got a thing to keep in mind is in your case we decided to try this study because of the genetic mutations that your tumor had. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, it wasn’t that we tried this study because you had exhausted all other options. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And the reason we’re saying that is because there are other things out there that your cancer has a good chance of responding well to. For example, uh, the alternative hormone therapy called Xtandi, that you have not received. You have received the one called, Zytiga. But there’s a similar one that was FDA approved about a year after the Zytiga was approved, called Xtandi. And it’s an oral hormone therapy pill. That medication does not work that well after people have received Zytiga first because it’s similarly related to that drug, but that’s an option. The second option is intravenous chemotherapy, which you have also not received. Um, which I know that you have been reluctant to think about it in the past, but that clearly is an option. So you have a minimum of two FDA-approved options that you have not tried yet. So knowing that, um, from my perspective, like I’m going to be a little less sort of heroic and like waiting to see if this is going to work or not. Because it’s not like you’ve run out of options, and this is the last thing we’re going to try anyway. You know? There are other options out there. Because we do have those options, yes, one of them is a chemo. Um, we also don’t want this cancer to advance too quickly that we miss the window and you get too sick and too frail, you know, to be able to tolerate those other therapies.

Patient: so no out-of-pocket for us? Doctor: Of gosh no that that you cannot get outside of the clinical trial. Patient: Really. Doctor: So you can’t get it if you tried. (Laughs) Patient: It’s so new. Uh and uh do you think within a month or two months we’ll know if it’s working? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah so I’m hoping to get you started within the next two or three weeks. Family Member: Oh yeah I mean we want to start right away. Patient: So do we schedule the appointment today? Doctor: For coming downtown? Yeah somebody will call you once we have everything. Patient: And so we’re not scheduling it today. Doctor: Do you want to come later on this week? Tell me what day works well and how long you need to think about the consent and everything? Patient: Just coming to the midtown? Family Member: To do the tests honey.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::strongly agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: The pestering is what it is. Doctor: Yeah, you shouldn’t just sit on it. Family Member: That’s what I told him, I said it’s gonna fall off if you don’t do something. Laughs]] Doctor: No I don’t think, no but the things way more… Patient: Are we on tape right now? Ah, we’ll talk about that later. Doctor: No but I’m surprised, how many months have you been putting up with this? A lot of time? Like years? Family Member: No, no. Six months, eight months? Patient: One year – well yeah right in there. Family Member: But it’s gotten… Patient: Well it – that statin helps. Family Member: Yeah he showed me though and it is… Doctor: Yeah but that’s a temporary fix. Patient: I know. I know it.

Family Member: All right. Doctor: That’s probably the best. Healthcare Professional: As a matter of fact, I’m going to go get schedule; I’ll be right back. Doctor: Easiest, in some ways, yeah. Healthcare Professional: I’m going to go get POS. Doctor: So, so I think now you’re going to - Family Member: And if that happens, what if all of a sudden he spikes a fever and it happens at night, uh - Doctor: Right, yeah, yeah, that’s right. No, one-eight hundred _____. That is like a twenty-four-hour line. Family Member: Right. Doctor: You can do it yourself, but then you’re flustered. It’s a little bit complicated, - Family Member: Yes, yes. Doctor: So that’s why I prefer; you know I tell people - Patient: Right, yes.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So, you know, probably, I mean, both of these probably two weeks. Patient: Did you get the results I emailed you. The DNA. Doctor: Yes. So, I got back the germline genetics testing. So this that this testing, well, do you remember? Tell me what you remember about that testing. The saliva testing that you did Patient: He was going to try to figure out um.. if this was hereditary or something. Doctor: Right, exactly. So that was negative for the, for the cancer causing gene. So that was negative. That is a different that's different than this. Patient: That’s different than this. Doctor: Yeah, because this this genotype that we're looking for- it does not predispose you to cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: This is something that's very common in the population. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We just think that these people are more likely to respond to antioxidants.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So with the Percocet you’re actually going lower on the dose of the OxyContin. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’re okay with that? Patient: Okay. What you think? Doctor: Well I don’t think it’s going to be all that much better for you, but if you think so I’m willing to give it a try instead of the Norco. Patient: Okay well I’m with you. Doctor: Keep taking the OxyContin in the morning and in the evening. Patient: Right. That’s what I do. Doctor: Don’t change that. Patient: That’s what I do. Doctor: Okay and then instead of the Norco you use the Percocet. Patient: Okay.

Patient: You know I’ve been you know after the surgery maybe about a about a month after that I was able to… Doctor: Okay. Patient: You know I was stopped wearing those things. Doctor: Pad, okay. Patient: You know and everything you know for maybe a few weeks I stopped wearing pads so I you know would make sure I’d put some tissue or something down in there. Doctor: Right, right. Patient: I might toot, but then after that no problems. Doctor: Very good. So it sounds like everything else is fine. Any new medical problems with your heart, lungs, bowels are functioning fine? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay fine. Patient: No. Doctor: So we just got to resolve this social issue.

Patient: How are you today? Doctor: Good timing. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I thought otherwise usually when I walk in you’re not here or something. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: That’s how it works out. Okay how are you feeling? How are the joints and everything else? Patient: Yeah, it’s all – it’s all good. Doctor: That’s all okay? Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: That has not acted up or gotten worse in the last few… Patient: No, no. Not since I went back on the prednisone. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’ve been fine since then.
